job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Grants Pass, OR
pros: Help some great people out!

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Salem, OR
pros: Flexible schedule and some co workers some times. Good experience as a stepping stone into in the field of psychology.
cons: People that just don't care are constantly and continually employed. People don't take their shifts seriously, i.e. leaving during the night portion of live in shifts and sleeping during the awake over night shift. I'm pretty sure a client died during my employment because of this very thing.

review_title: Careless to Safety, Promotes Gang like Mentality
pros: Encourages management and staff to cover up abusive behaviors and practices with little to no training. Pros at creating gang culture mentality when injured on the job and looks over drug use by staff.
cons: Encouragement not to report abuse against staff. Upper management plays blaming games when confronted. HIPPA violations in regards to staff injuries and are quick to twist facts about staff members who do not keep quiet about abuse towards residents and drug use of employees.

job_title: Direct Care Professional in Monmouth, OR
pros: A great job while I was in college.
cons: Once I graduated from college I was ready for change. I appreciate the time I spent with PCL and all they did for me while I was in college.

pros:
Getting to know the people I supported
Decent pay compared to other entry-level jobs without experience
Set schedule with many shifts to choose from
Benefits
cons:
Exploitative and retaliatory company culture
Unsafe work environment
Poor work-life balance
Poor pay for the type of work
Unresponsive and unhelpful HR
Harassment and discrimination of workers

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Eugene, OR
pros: You get to do good work supporting people in need and get great, real-world experience working with people you might not see or interact with in your day-to-day life. The pay is also decent, and there are lots of opportunities to earn prizes and bonuses.
cons: Despite what they might say, the company doesn't actually care about its employees. You work long shifts (8 hours is a short day) with no breaks, often working alone with no support. It's extremely stressful and you can burn out quickly if you're not careful. You are constantly flooded with shift coverage requests via email and management is so overworked that if you bring a concern to them, it'll likely get ignored. They are doing extremely high-stakes work with burnt-out employees and no room for error, everything is down to the wire all the time.

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Medford, OR
pros:
Make an impact in other's lives.
Single benefits affordable
cons:
family benefits not subsidized.
can be stressful

review_title: Cares for the people they employ and support.

pros:
one over the better company's ive worked for. 
ok benefits. easy to get on

review_title: Owners support such a good cause, yet overlook the management who run out good employees :(
job_title: Service Team Coordinator in Monmouth, OR
pros: Good money, lots of mistakes without trouble. Flexible schedules available thru out the areas they support.
cons: They are so understaffed that the people supported are the ones who suffer. The few employees that are loyal are so overworked and yeah they are compensated with pay, and the area managers treat them like they are so disposable yet they are the backbone to the survival of this company. The truth is that the hands on management who have been there for 5-10 years are monsters. If they like you one minute and not the next then they bully great employees who love what they do and its the people the owners support who suffer. If they put that effort into empowering the employees they could make serious waves in the right direction for the community of folks they support.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Monmouth, OR
pros: I really enjoyed working with the people that were supported. It was a lot of fun seeing them grow and challenge themselves in good ways.
cons: EXTREMELY POOR MANAGEMENT.  Needs more organization

pros: It is awesome watching the people supported learn and grow .I have made some great friends and connections.I loved playing with them and taking them out on outings.
cons: Pay sucks...I have gotten one raise in almost 4 years and my pay is still lower then other company's.  The odds of injury are really high,and they expect you to work no matter what ,if you are sick the response is often there is no one to cover you.The odds of promotion are slim to none unless you are in tight with some one in upper management. Open door policy is there but nothing changes after that.There are a few good managers but most are on there own agenda. If there is an issue with your supervisor management will automatically take there side no matter what.

pros:
Making a difference in the people's life that we support , it's not just have a fun day going to the movies or big vacations. It's just knowing that in the end of the day that smile you help create is worth everything to them and to your self.

You get out and help build life's and create a lifetime of memories. Learning that you really do have a lot to give this is a place to shine.
cons:
Long hours, under staffed, under paid. Health benifits aren't great but better then having none the cost could be lower so more staff can afford it. 

Staff should get more aknowleagment for what they do, not just a popularity contest. Everyone should know there doing a good job and when they do they do more fulfill more dreams for the people we support. 
You give us the support and encouragement and it will be shown through out.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Monmouth, OR
pros: This is honestly the best job I've ever had. I am valued and respected as an employee, and in turn am encouraged to extend that value and respect to the people I support. I really am given the opportunities that were promised to me during the training. And overall the culture and the atmosphere reflect the mission statement: To Expand The Horizons And Enhance The Quality Of Life For Those We Support.
cons: This kind of work can be demanding at times. Some places require 24 hour staffing. That means that I can be potentially working at any time. However my supervisor is always very good about asking for help. I really do feel like I can say "no" if I'm unable to come in and I'm still treated in a respectful way.

pros:
I have worked for many companies before and have never been treated so well before. The founders make sure everyone knows they are appreciated on a regular basis. They get each member of leadership a personal Christmas present which they hand pick and wrap, They get everyone anniversary gifts for when they started at PCL, they recognize all the good people are doing at every all staff meeting (once every 1-2 months), and they even have an annual BBQ just to recognize and celebrate the support staff.  It's amazing how much they do to make sure everyone feels appreciated. 
Other good things would be:
-Family oriented. 
-There is always someone to mentor you
-The people we work with are amazing and so much fun to hang out with 
-Your house team becomes like a second family. 
-Leadership is very transparent about funding and the legislative process.
cons:
-Staff turnover is high
-not the best pay, but what can we expect from a nonprofit?

review_title: Happy but have some things to talk about
pros: i feel like i can make a difference in someones life where she might fall behind without support. i feel a sense of fullfilment when working with sarah and find that we have so much in common actually,
cons: i believe that if one person is not allowed to wear a certain kind of clothing all should not be able to wear it. first day i was understandably told that my pants were not appropiate as they did have some paint splatters. i and others wore fashing ripped jeans and i was called out on it after wearing them more than once and no one else was, also, i think that if someone is wearing track pants that they should be held to the same standard as everyone else.

pros:
All the people supported here that I have met have been wonderful.

The houses are nice, lots of room to work and resources to help with work.
cons:
Favoritism.

Supervisors seldom have time to mentor or help dsps. 

High stress and many responsibilities.

Low pay, a little above minimum wage.

review_title: If you love the work you do you will never work another day in your life.
pros: Mission focus.  Team environment. Cares about employees and very family focused.  Positions available in several locations and a wide variety of hours.  Allows for a lot of flexibility.  The work we do is can be hard, but we have a lot of fun doing it.
cons: Due to growth  there are a lot of open positions, so many are working a lot of hours.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Salem, OR
pros: great people that are supported. Do fun hings and keep it a good work atmosphere. Tons of hours available to those who love OT. Variety.
cons: some management are not always on your side. They gossip and talk down about their employees rather then help progress and move on. When brought up the management was defended.

pros: The people we support are amazing ,I love them all
cons: Favoritism,advancement is only possible for those who are tight with upper management,even if STC is wrong management still supports them and dsps are told to deal with it. When a DSP is sick they are often told there is no coverage you need to come in.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Salem, OR
pros: Working at P.C.L For the past two years has been some of the most rewarding time of my life. Not only have i gotten to meet some really grate employees but the people that i support are so awesome. We go on outings every weekend and  have so much fun getting out in the community and expanding our horizons.
cons: Nothing working for P.C.L Is grate i would not change a thing.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Monmouth, OR
pros: The community is outgoing and kind. I feel welcomed and encouraged to ask questions. The atmosphere is very positive. Training is informative.
cons: For entry-level workers, the base wage is admittedly low (benefits compensate for this to some extent). Advancement tends to be a slow process. The learning curve is overwhelming at first, but you acclimate quickly on the job.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Eugene, OR
pros: PCL really cares about their employees, as well as each other. Everyone works as a team and is sure that they have the same goal in mind. Working with the individuals in the program is not only fun, but can be life changing.
cons: Working as a Direct Support Professional can be challenging at times. It can take some time to get fully trained and comfortable.

pros: I've learned a lot about myself in this job. This work requires working closely with your coworkers and I've made some very solid friendships.
cons: There are a couple of upper managers who don't know or don't remember what the entry level work is like.

review_title: Overall Review of My Experiences Thus Far

pros: PCL is incredibly willing to work with employees, regarding days off, correct house placements, and providing any clarification requested.
cons: I have yet to find a con to working at PCL, although I am very new.

pros: Great culture, important work, fun environment, you get fed a lot, you get to be part of something bigger, you get to make a positive impact on people's lives.
